moves.6... dxc4: This is a riskier move, allowing White to develop more quickly.
moves.7. Bxc4 Be7 8. O-O O-O 9. Qe2: This is a strong move, restraining ...e5 and allowing Rooks to pressure on the e and later the d-file.
moves.13. Bd2 Bxc3: ?! gives up the bishop pair and strengthens whites center.
moves.14. bxc3 a6 15. c4: To drive the N back, preparing to exploit greater space and the bishop pair.
moves.15... Nb6: ?? This actually loses a piece after Ba5. Best was ...Nc7.
moves.16... Bd7: ? Best was ...Nd7, saving the piece and trying to force exchanges.
moves.17. Ba5: ! Finally. From now on Black is clearly lost. No way to save the N because if the Q moves the N is lost and otherwise c5 wins the N due to the pin.
Winning the N and constricting Black further.
moves.21... Qc6 22. Rad1 g6: ? Best not to voluntarily open the dark squares around the K when you are missing a DSB.
moves.23. Qe2 Rfe8 24. Qe5: Whites plan is simple. Provoke weaknesses on the Kingside.
moves.24... Rac8 25. Ba5: Simplest. White brings the DSB back and is still prepared to bring the R up as well. Black can't afford to exchange, or not to exchange.
moves.27. Qe3: No need to exchange, it is quicker to rake the Kingside which is undefended.
moves.27... g5: ? Leads to a quick end, but Black had no counterplay.
moves.28... Qf4: ? Now White has a quick win...
moves.29. Qxh6 Bc6 30. d5: ! Obvious but deadly. Mate on g7 can only be deferred by giving up too much material. Black resigns.
